channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Obama Loosens Restrictions on U.S. Forces Fighting Taliban in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Members of the Afghan Army trained in Helmand Province in March.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The president moved closer to allowing American forces to again directly battle the Taliban in what is expected to be an especially bloody summer fighting season.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 5 Get Life Sentences in India for Rape of Danish Woman in 2014
item.media:description: Two of the five men convicted in the rape of a Danish tourist in 2014 were escorted from court by the police on Thursday in New Delhi. All five men were sentenced to life in prison on Friday.
item.description: The case was said to have “wide ramifications” for India, where an intense national debate about the problem of sexual violence has been taking place.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Volunteer at Hindu Ashram in Bangladesh is Hacked to Death
item.media:description: The body of Nityaranjan Pandey, a volunteer at a Hindu ashram, after assailants hacked him to death in Pabna, Bangladesh, on Friday.
item.description: The death of Nityaranjan Pandey in the district of Pabna adds to a string of violent attacks in the country.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: At Birthplace of Brazil’s Corruption Scandal, Talk of Scraping By
item.media:description: The Posto da Torre, or Tower Gas Station, in Brasília last year.
item.description: “Operation Car Wash” has shaken Brazil’s elite and fueled anger among the lower classes about epic and systemic corruption.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and PAULA MOURA

item.title: Drug That Killed Prince Is Making Mexican Cartels Richer, U.S. Says
item.media:description: Prince performing during halftime of the Super Bowl in Miami in 2007. The music icon, who struggled with debilitating pain, died from an accidental overdose of fentanyl in April.
item.description: American officials warn that the cartels are using their own labs to produce fentanyl, a synthetic opioid tied to a rise in overdose deaths.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Pedro Kuczynski Declares Victory Over Keiko Fujimori for Peru Presidency
item.media:description: Keiko Fujimori, the populist rival of Mr. Kuczynski, had not conceded on Thursday.
item.description: Mr. Kuczynski, an economist, appeared to have narrowly prevailed over the populist Keiko Fujimori, the daughter of an imprisoned former president.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Besieged Syrian Town Gets First Food Aid Since 2012, Then Gets Bombed
item.description: Relief trucks delivered food to Daraya, a town outside Damascus, but residents reported that it was soon bombed by the Syrian military.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Kurdish Militant Group T.A.K. Claims Responsibility for Istanbul Bombing
item.media:description: A canvas protected the facade of a hotel in Istanbul on Wednesday. The hotel was damaged in a car bombing that killed 11 people on Tuesday.
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Falcons, affiliated with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers’ Party, said it was behind the attack that killed 11 people.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: British Judge Orders Proper Pay for Exploited Migrant Workers
item.description: The Lithuanian workers, who caught chickens, were not paid minimum wage and were charged illegal fees, and their wages were improperly withheld.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Replica of Noah’s Ark Is Damaged in Oslo Harbor Collision
item.media:description: A replica of Noah’s ark was damaged after colliding with a Norwegian Coast Guard vessel in Oslo on Friday.
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.description: A large model of the ship collided with a Coast Guard boat on Friday. No people (or animals) were injured during the crash.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Russian Cybersleuth Battles the ‘Dark Ages’ of the Internet
item.media:description: “We are living in the middle cyberage, the dark ages of cyber,” said Eugene V. Kaspersky, the founder and chief executive of the global computer security company Kaspersky Lab.
item.media:credit: Valeri Nistratov for The New York Times
item.description: Eugene V. Kaspersky, one of the world’s foremost authorities on cybersecurity, is worried — very worried — about threats most people cannot even imagine.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: U.N.-Backed Libyan Fighters Push Toward ISIS Stronghold of Surt
item.media:description: Soldiers from forces aligned with Libya’s new unity government on Wednesday, during an advance on the Islamic State stronghold of Surt.
item.description: The Libyan ground offensive, led by a brigade from the city of Misurata, has gradually closed in on Surt, a coastal town nearby, from the west and south.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Keiko Fujimori Concedes in Peru’s Presidential Election
item.description: Ms. Fujimori, a daughter of a former leader, congratulated Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a former finance minister, who won by 42,000 votes.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Fire at Refugee Shelter in Germany Followed a Dispute Over Ramadan, Police Say
item.media:description: The wreckage of exhibition halls used as refugee camps in Düsseldorf, Germany, after a fire on Tuesday.
item.description: The blaze on Tuesday in Düsseldorf broke out after a meal service was reduced in consideration for residents observing Ramadan, when many Muslims fast during the day.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Tibet Stands Out in China’s Entries at Shanghai International Film Festival
item.media:description: Jinpa as Tabei, left, and Choenyi Tsering as Chung in “Soul on a String,” directed by Zhang Yang and based on a story by the prominent Tibetan writer Tashi Dawa. The actors and the dialogue in the film are Tibetan.
item.description: “De Lan,” by the director Liu Jie, and “Soul on a String,” by Zhang Yang, highlight a shift in the cinematic depiction of ethnic minorities, especially Tibetans.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Greed, Passion, Lust, Betrayal, and the Olympics in Between
item.media:description: The actresses Nathalia Dill, left, and Juliana Carneiro da Cunha on the set of the telenovela “Liberdade, Liberdade,” at Globo’s studios in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: In Brazil, the popular TV serials called telenovelas have so tight a grip on viewers that even the Olympics on home turf take a back seat in prime time.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Syria Violence Leads U.N. Envoy to Push Back Date for Peace Talks
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike last week in a rebel-controlled neighborhood in Aleppo, Syria. Russian and Syrian government airstrikes have resumed with increasing intensity on the rebel-held eastern side of Aleppo.
item.description: Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations’ special envoy for Syria, said the time was not right for negotiations but emphasized that they must resume by early August.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: An American Found in Iraq Fleeing From ISIS Is Charged
item.description: Federal prosecutors argued that Mohamad Jamal Khweis, a former bank teller, joined the Islamic State in Syria and pledged to become a suicide bomber.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Film About Russian Lawyer’s Death Creates an Uproar
item.media:description: Sergei L. Magnitsky
item.description: Critics are trying to block a Washington screening of a documentary that portrays Sergei L. Magnitsky, who died in a Moscow prison cell, as an accomplice rather than a victim.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: The Magnitsky Act -- Behind the Scenes (Movie)

item.title: Period. Full Stop. Point. Whatever It’s Called, It’s Going Out of Style
item.media:description: “We are at a momentous moment in the history of the full stop,” said David Crystal, who has written more than 100 books on language
item.description: Language experts say one of the oldest forms of punctuation is going out of fashion, felled by the staccato sentences favored in instant messaging
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: A Steel Mill Lives Again, in a Setback for China
item.media:description: Songting Iron & Steel Mill’s smokestacks jut out from the surrounding landscape.
item.media:credit: Nicola Longobardi for The New York Times
item.description: Local officials and businesses buck Beijing’s efforts to close the inefficient industries that are hobbling the country’s economic growth.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHUMAN

item.title: Ex-Vice President of Maldives Convicted of Trying to Kill President
item.media:description: Ahmed Adeeb, the former vice president of the Maldives. Mr. Adeeb had denied the assassination charges, pointing to a report by the F.B.I. that found no evidence of a bomb on President Abdulla Yameen’s boat.
item.media:credit: Ali Naseer/Sun Media Group, via Associated Press
item.description: Ahmed Adeeb was accused of masterminding a plot to kill President Abdulla Yameen by planting a bomb on his speedboat last year. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: ZAHEENA RASHEED and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi, Former Leader of Italy, to Have Heart Surgery
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi in 2014. His doctor said he required surgery for a leaking aortic valve.
item.description: Mr. Berlusconi’s doctor said the former prime minister “risked dying” without surgery to replace a defective heart valve.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Suicide Bombings Kill Dozens in Baghdad Area
item.media:description: A firefighter after a blaze was extinguished at the site of car bomb attack in the New Baghdad district of the Iraqi capital on Thursday.
item.description: The deadliest assault killed at least 19 in a Shiite neighborhood in Baghdad. A second attack near the capital killed at least 12.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Volkswagen Not Alone in Flouting Pollution Limits
item.media:description: Axel Friedrich, a co-founder of the International Council on Clean Transportation, which commissioned the tests that exposed Volkswagen’s cheating. “It’s not just fraud — it’s physical assault,” he said.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Other carmakers in Europe have taken advantage of a loophole that allows them to reduce emissions controls whenever there is risk of engine damage.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Questions About Suspect’s Identity Circle Human Trafficking Case
item.media:description: Left, Medhanie Yehdego Mered, a well-known human trafficker. Right, Italian police officers with the man they took into custody on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Left, National Crime Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency; Right, Italian National Police
item.description: Doubts about the identity of an Eritrean suspect taken into custody were raised within hours of the announcement that an arrest had been made.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON, JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Tighter Rules on Money Transfers Put Squeeze on Businesses
item.media:description: An Interamericana Express in Atlantic City. Mexico is the biggest destination for money transfers from the United States, according to estimates by the World Bank.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: Banks are refusing to do business with money transmitters, closing or freezing accounts over concerns about money laundering and regulatory scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: ELINOR COMLAY

item.title: Shabab Attack in Somalia Sets Off Predawn Gun Battle
item.description: Militants stormed an African Union base after an explosive-laden car rammed into the gates, and scores of soldiers and militants were killed in the gun battle that followed.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Delay Pregnancy in Areas With Zika, W.H.O. Suggests
item.media:description: A pregnant woman at a hospital in Honduras, where the Zika virus is circulating.
item.description: The advice affects millions of couples in 46 countries across Latin America and the Caribbean where Zika transmission is occurring or expected.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Memo From Britain: Brexit Vote Gives Tabloids Chance to Unleash Anti-European Tendencies
item.media:description: Britain’s freewheeling tabloid press has never been shy about pushing an agenda.
item.description: The hostility of some papers to the European Union is a problem for Prime Minister David Cameron, who is trying to persuade Britons to vote to remain.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: United Nations Chief Exposes Limits to His Authority by Citing Saudi Threat
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said he removed a Saudi-led coalition that is bombing Yemen from a list of children’s rights violators after the Saudis threatened to withhold funding.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trilobites: Scientists Find Genes That Let These Bees Reproduce Without Males
item.media:description: Researchers studied the genomes of a population of honeybees in South Africa, Cape bees, that often reproduce without males.
item.description: In a subspecies of honey bees from South Africa, female workers can escape a queen’s control and produce offspring of their own. Scientists say a gene explains how.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Iceland Carbon Dioxide Storage Project Locks Away Gas, and Fast
item.media:description: The CarbFix project uses carbon dioxide that bubbles up naturally with the hot magma that powers the Hellisheidi Geothermal Power Station in Iceland.
item.media:credit: Bara Kristinsdottir for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers report success in an experiment that keeps a gas tied to global warming out of the atmosphere permanently.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: India Film Censor Orders 94 Cuts to Movie About Punjab’s Drug Problem
item.media:description: Anurag Kashyap, the producer of “Flying Punjab,” talked about the censorship of his film at a news conference this week.
item.description: The producer of the movie “Flying Punjab” has turned to the Bombay High Court after he was ordered to remove any reference to Punjab.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: VW Manager in Germany Is Said to Have Pushed for Removing Evidence
item.media:description: The power plant of the Volkswagen factory in Wolfsburg, Germany. Volkswagen employees in Germany told investigators they were encouraged to delete or remove documents weeks before the emissions scandal became public.
item.media:credit: Ben Kilb for The New York Times
item.description: Volkswagen employees in Germany told investigators they were encouraged to delete or remove documents weeks before the emissions scandal became public.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Letter From Europe: Against Parkinson’s, Muhammad Ali Proved Himself Again
item.media:description: Muhammad Ali, seated, was one of the Olympic flag bearers at the London Games in 2012. Despite the challenges of Parkinson’s disease, Ali did not shy from public view.
item.description: For those with Parkinson’s disease, Ali’s 30-year struggle with the same illness magnified the broader status he built from his boxing prowess.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Uber and Its Executives Are Fined in France
item.media:description: Taxi drivers taking a break during a protest in January in Paris against companies like Uber.
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The popular ride-booking service and two French executives must pay almost $500,000 for breaking the country’s tough transportation rules.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Arrest of Homa Hoodfar in Iran Shines Light on Dangers for Dual Citizens
item.media:description: Homa Hoodfar, a Canadian-Iranian professor, was rearrested in Iran last week.
item.description: The detention of the Canadian-Iranian professor, who researches women in the Muslim world, shows a shift by hard-liners, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Israelis Find Rare Moment of Solidarity in Aftermath of Tel Aviv Shootings
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers at a checkpoint on Thursday outside the West Bank town of Yatta. Israeli police said the Palestinian gunmen who killed four people in Tel Aviv on Wednesday were from Yatta.
item.description: A day after gunmen killed four people in a cafe, the authorities suspended travel permits and sent two battalions of soldiers to the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Ireland Abortion Ban Violated Woman’s Human Rights, U.N. Panel Says
item.media:description: A protest in Dublin in 2012, after doctors refused to perform an abortion on Savita Halappanavar, who died after having a miscarriage.
item.description: The case centered on a Dublin woman who traveled abroad to terminate her pregnancy after being told her fetus had severe congenital defects.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: A Rising Chinese Actor, Dong Zijian, on Where the Good Movies Are Now
item.media:description: Dong Zijian, left, in Liu Jie’s new film “De Lan,” which has been nominated for a Golden Goblet as best feature film at this year’s Shanghai International Film Festival.
item.description: Ahead of the Shanghai International Film Festival, Mr. Dong discussed his favorite directors, the changing market and what happened to art-house films.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Japan Summons Chinese Envoy After Naval Ship Nears Disputed Islands
item.media:description: The uninhabited island chain, known as the Senkaku in Japan and the Diaoyu in China, in 2012. A Chinese frigate was spotted less than 24 nautical miles from the chain and left after about two hours, Japan said.
item.description: China often sends patrol vessels to the contested East China Sea waters, but a naval ship had never appeared there before Thursday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Dog Meat Festival Is Again at Hand, and Opponents Are Lining Up
item.media:description: Dogs on sale at a marketplace in Yulin during the city’s dog meat festival last year.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A petition to stop the event that organizers said had attracted more than 11 million signatures was presented to the Chinese Embassy in London as well delivered to officials in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: A French Minister Who Inspires Applause and Anger Considers a Bigger Stage
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, center, the French economy minister, with José Ángel Gurría, left, secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, at a meeting this month in Paris.
item.description: Emmanuel Macron has started what many consider a campaign in all but name to explore whether to challenge François Hollande as the Socialist candidate for president.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: What in the World: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
item.media:description: A former German bunker in Mamerki, Poland. Researchers have uncovered evidence of a hidden chamber inside, and think it may contain loot from World War II.
item.description: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Chinese Delicacy Straight From the Swiftlet’s Mouth
item.media:description: A caretaker held a bird’s nest and egg at the Swiftlet Eco Park in Perak, Malaysia, last year. Prized in China for their alleged health benefits, nests made from swiftlets’ saliva are a delicacy.
item.description: Bird’s nest soup, including bird saliva, is supposed to improve the immune system, skin and sex drive. The demand means trouble for the birds themselves.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: An All-Purpose Maze Deep Beneath a London Suburb
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photos by Jag_cz, Andrey Yurlov, Ollie, Graeme Dawes/shutterstock
item.description: The Chislehurst Caves have been an arsenal, a bomb shelter, a concert site, a film set, and once even a makeshift maternity ward. But they’ve never been caves.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Exposures: The Child Migrants of Africa
item.media:description: Ablie, 17, Fodaoi, 14, and Alieu, 17, all from Gambia, at the center for unaccompanied minors in Pozzallo.
item.description: The Italian government has largely kept reporters from entering the shelters and interviewing refugees.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY GILBERTSON
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Europe and the Unthinkable
item.description: The collapse of the European Union is implausible but not impossible. It is time to awaken to the dangers.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Common-Sense Steps to Deal With the Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants on the Italian Navy vessel Grecale off Sicily in May. In the first five months of this year, 48,000 migrants were rescued from the Canale di Sicilia section of the central Mediterranean.
item.description: People have been crossing the Mediterranean for years, trying to get to Italy. Why can’t the Continent come up with a good response?
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: ‘Named a Chevalier of the French Legion? Me?’ — Reporter’s Notebook.
item.media:description: Steven Erlanger, left, with the French diplomat Jean-David Levitte and America’s ambassador to France, Jane Hartley, at the United States embassy in Paris on June 2.
item.description: The former Paris bureau chief Steven Erlanger was surprised to learn he has been honored as a chevalier — or knight — by France.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
